jcr:content.jcr:title: Preliminary Design of an Experimental World-Circling Spaceship

contentheadline.headline: Preliminary Design of an Experimental World-Circling Spaceship

contentrichtext.text: [[File:The Air Force Role In Developing International Outer Space Law (Terrill, 1999) Page 004-1.jpg|right]] The '''Preliminary Design of an Experimental World-Circling Spaceship''' was a 1946 proposal by [[Project RAND]] for a United States [[satellite]] program. Dr. [[Robert M. Salter]], Jack Lipp, and one other person at RAND served as the editors of the report.<ref>http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1875/1</ref> The Preliminary Design of an Experimental World-Circling Spaceship states, ''"A satellite vehicle with appropriate instrumentation can be expected to be one of the most potent [[science|scientific]] [[tool]]s of the Twentieth Century. The achievement of a satellite craft would produce repercussions comparable to the explosion of the [[atomic bomb]]..."'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.rand.org/pubs/special_memoranda/SM11827/index.html Book for sale or free download] at RAND website [[Category:Spaceflight]] [[Category:Hypothetical spacecraft]] [[Category:RAND Corporation]] <!--{{rocket-stub}}--> {{spacecraft-stub}}
